body: Yea, Pig is really bad at isolating per InputFormat configurations. This does seem like a Pig problem though and not an InputFormat problem. I hope this can be solved at Pig layer.

@jerryshao, it felt like processing the same amount of data would give us better stability for the pipeline as 100 files in one batch can contain more data than 100 files in the next batch. Also, the number of tasks felt like a direct consequence of the data size. @rdblue, what was your reasoning?

@rdblue , The reason for passing in name mapping in row group filter is because we build metadata mapping from footer which may contain incompatible columns with passing `typeWithIds`. I removed the name mapping through a try/catch block to solve that.

The original plan is to replace all ID-based `ParquetValueReader` to the name-based readers because the `NameBaseReadBuilder` builds a `ParquetValueReader` that doesn't need any schema ID. That is why I use the original file schema instead of `typeWithIds`. But there is no harm to pass a `MessageType` with IDs to build the name-based readers. so in the latest commit, I use `typeWithIds` for both ways.
Thanks @rdblue , I have fixed it, would mind to take another look?
I will move `UpdatePartitionSpec` and all related unit tests to another PR.

Look great! +1.

I will rebase https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/pull/588 once this get in.
Sorry for update late, I have send a another PR https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/pull/911 to unify the usage of Preconditions
Hi @rdblue , can you help to review? thanks
Merged. Thanks @leoluan2009!

I think we will also need a test that can be added to `TestIcebergSourceTablesBase`. It should start with an empty table, stage a snapshot or two and verify the records returned by `all_data_files` and `all_manifests`.

The number of files is only a good proxy for the amount of data to process _if_ the files are approximately the same size. That's not the case for many tables, so I think using number of files would lead to batches that process lots of data and batches that process only a little.
No problem about the timing, I was just trying to keep the number of PRs manageable. You're always welcome to re-open or re-submit if that happens.
@XiaokunDing, it looks like the wrong branch was pushed here?
I'm going to close this since we don't need to track it as an issue.
I'd love to remove guava. The main blocker is replacing Guava's collections. We use ImmutableMap and ImmutableList quite a bit, and I don't know of a good alternative.

I'm merging this since it's large and the remaining comments are minor. That avoids needing to re-read the whole commit for small updates. Thanks for adding this, @aokolnychyi! I think it is going to be really useful.
Instead of making spec changes in each v2 commit I'm using a v2-spec PR, #912. That way we don't trigger CI runs in PRs that are waiting to be merged for updates to the spec.
The changes LGTM. +1

Spark also has the same issue: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SPARK-29245

Will be solved in Hive 2.3.7 as I understand it: https://www.mail-archive.com/dev@hive.apache.org/msg138085.html

RC should be there soon: http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/hive-dev/202004.mbox/browser

I have been working with the Hive community to get a Hive 2.3.7 release out which should resolve this issue and allow the usage of Hive libraries on JDK >=9. A release candidate has been created (you can test it out if you want - https://repository.apache.org/content/repositories/orgapachehive-1100/) and here is the discussion on the Hive dev list where a release has been proposed - http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/hive-dev/202004.mbox/%3CCANQiJeXh9hVma%3DA88vPLnWtguDfw%2BrZ4%2BoqeoYTMsfDZyxQNgg%40mail.gmail.com%3E. As soon as that is released I would recommend Iceberg change its default Hive version to 2.3.7 instead of 2.3.6.
Thanks, @Fokko!
Thanks for reviewing @rdsr!

@rdsr, @aokolnychyi, FYI.

The changes to Avro and Parquet to use a constants map didn't filter by identity transforms, so non-identity partition data values were accidentally replaced causing test failures in `TestRemoveOrphanFilesAction` (the truncated fields). This is a fix for the problem that I'll merge to master when tests are passing to stop failing PRs.
Thanks @aokolnychyi , I have fixed it, would mind to take another look?
HI @rdblue I have squashed  all about this   Pull requests commit to one, and change a branch for this PR at #919
Thanks for the update @massdosage. I'll keep an eye out on the Hive RC's so I can test those here as well.

Hi @rdblue @jerryshao, I'm working on the reader and writer for delete files. As for the reader, the input and output are clear as the delete files would be extracted from `FileScanTask` and the output would be iterable of `InternalRow` or `GenericRecord`. While for the writer, I 'm not very sure since how metadata-level delete will be implemented. For the spark engine, I could imagine two possible ways:

- spark build the table scan with the filter expression and projection of the partition columns and metadata columns then save the data frame in append mode with an option like `data=diff`. In this case, Iceberg can generate partition level delete files from the input partition. That means we may not need a separate writer, maybe some update in the current table writer.

- spark has a logical plan `RowDeleteScan` like the table scan, each task read the input file with filter(residual) and then write to delete file.  In this case, we need a separate writer that takes the input file and filter expression as input and writes the filtered records. This would need residual evaluation for every supported format, but we can use `IcebergGenerics` to handle this.

Both of them depend on spark side implementation, any thought?

I think it's a good idea to add ORC schema visitors. I've found them helpful for Avro and Parquet because the recursive traversal is abstracted from the logic of each visitor. It's been easy to build new visitors. So I'm +1.

I also want to point out that this doesn't have to be one big refactor. We can keep the current code as it is and just use the visitors for new things, and slowly convert over to the visitors in places where it makes sense. A minimal start is to define the visitor interface and visit method, then use it for what you need to, like the read builder in this case.

I believe Anton's latest work to cleanup orphan files https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/pull/894 helps this case coz any dangling files would not show up in `all_data_files` and hence get cleaned up. Although there is still handling to be done here. Will take this up to address pending issues.
Thanks @prodeezy! It would be great to fix the problem where a failure while reading manifests causes this problem.
HI @rdblue I have fixed it, would mind to take another look?

The object model used by these files can be swapped out just like any Avro file. If we want to pass this information to Spark, then we would use the Spark reader classes. For most internals, we build classes that implement `IndexedRecord`.

@chenjunjiedada FYI, I refactored the code and the partition spec evolution changes and related tests are now in https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/pull/922. Thanks.

+1 when tests pass.

Thanks for working on this, @jun-he!

Besides my comment about replacing the entire spec, I have two other main concerns. First, I think we might want to consider a change-based API, which is related to my comment about not replacing the whole spec. For updating schemas, the API expresses things like addColumn, renameColumn, etc. that correspond to SQL DDL statements. I think it would make sense to have a similar API here:
* `addField(String source, ...)`
* `renameField(String name, String newName)`
* `replaceField(String name, ...)`
* `removeField(String name)`

I'm not sure how we should pass the transform to `addField` and `replaceField` just yet. We have expressions for the various transforms, so we could use an expression like `addField("ts_hour", hour("ts"))`. We could also add a lot more variations of the method names, like `addHourField`, `addDayField`, etc.

Second, I think we are going to need a v1 version and a v2 version. In v1, we have to maintain the order and number of fields, so we are more limited for partition spec evolution: we can rename partition fields, replace existing partition fields with the `void` transform to "remove" them, and add new partition fields at the end of the spec. But in v2, we have reliable IDs so we can actually remove fields, replace a field with a different transform (drop days and add hours in the same position), also rename and add partition fields. I think the easiest thing is to build separate implementations that validate and apply those changes.
Looks good to me, but I'd prefer to add retries if we can.
Good catch, @garawalid. Thanks for submitting this!
I'm merging this because I ran tests locally and they are passing.
Ran tests locally and they are passing, so I'm going to merge this.
#924 just made it in, so this can implement `dropField` for v1 by replacing the field with a `void` transform. That will avoid ID problems.

I think the intent is to keep testing against the latest because that's the most important version to work with. All of the 2.4.x releases should be compatible, so this doesn't constrain which versions of Spark Iceberg works with. It just pulls in the latest bug fixes.
Thanks @rdblue
This is now addressed by https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/pull/922. Thanks, @jun-he!

@aokolnychyi @rdblue would you please help to review the current implementation? I did a new round of refactoring to use the way @aokolnychyi proposed, please help to review if this is a feasible solution.
While I still need to add Javadoc and tests for `DataFile` and `StructLike` wrappers, this PR is ready for another review round. If the approach is OK, I'll submit the wrappers in a separate PR.

Glue doesn't support Hive table locking, so there is no atomic operation we can use for the metadata update. If that's changed, then we would gladly add a Glue metastore. I recommend talking to your AWS point of contact if you want this.
Sounds good. Could you open a PR?
HI @aokolnychyi @rdblue do we need Implement an action to rewrite dataFile?
@rdblue , I don't quite follow the last comment. Do you mean the object model for delete files could be Avro in-memory data model so that it could be used by other engines as well?
Thanks @XiaokunDing, I committed this.

Whatever is consuming the file can use its own object model. When Iceberg loads metadata files, we use classes that extend `IndexedRecord` so that Avro can construct them directly like a specific record. An example of this is `GenericDataFile`.

However, there are cases where the metadata files are read by engines, like the metadata tables. When you read the `entries` metadata table, Iceberg creates tasks out of the manifest Avro files and Spark reads the data as InternalRow directly.

Delete files would be similar to these cases. If the engine needs to read a delete file, it would be able to use its object model with Avro. But I think that we will need an `IndexedRecord` implementation for file/position deletes so that we can build a filter that merges that stream with a data file record stream.
@rdsr, I've missed the sync. Is this needed for people who depend on `core`?

@rdblue, do we need to update `TestSparkReadProjection` to use this conversion logic too? It seems that test won't handle dates and timestamps as Spark `Row` returns `java.sql.Date` and `java.sql.Timestamp` respectively.

Hi @aokolnychyi , @massdosage and team are working on a HiveStorageHandler which would go in `iceberg-hive` module. I think they have faced class-path issues relying on iceberg core modules together with hive artifacts in `iceberg-hive`

I too faced an issue with Guava where I was unable to run Mini HDFS to test iceberg-mr because of guava conflicts.

One minor issue I see now is that there's no table and db name in the update classes, which would be very helpful to add it to the update event. One option I'm considering is exposing a `tableIdentifier()` from `TableOperations` API
@rdblue Yep. I will open a PR a bit later.
@rdblue thank for your patience
`tableIdentifier()` may not make sense for `HadoopTableOperations`, maybe be can provide a `tablePath` api which both Hadoop and MetastoreOperations can implement?
Planning to take this up next week unless someone is working on it
Thanks @rdblue . I'm taking this up to support #897

Yes, `iceberg-hive` depends on `iceberg-core`, `iceberg-api`, `iceberg-common` and `iceberg-mr` so all of these jar files will need to go on Hive's classpath when you use any of the classes inside iceberg-hive. Due to Guava version conflicts with the version of Guava used by Hive all usages of Guava inside Iceberg's classes need to be shaded and reolcated otherwise there are runtime version conflicts which prevent being able to integrate Iceberg and Hive. I would imagine there would be similar issues with anyone using any Iceberg modules via an API and also having their own version of Guava so would recommend applying this across the whole project if possible.
@rdsr we'd appreciate your input on this one as to next steps please

@aokolnychyi can you please assign this issue to me?
I am new to this repository and would like to contribute.
Hive 2.3.7 was released over the weekend but I think you already noticed! :)

+1 from me. @rdsr, any more comments?
Hi @rdblue I've created a PR. Could you have a look?
Let me go through this right now.
+1. I'll merge. Thanks @chenjunjiedada
Thank you for contributing this, @chenjunjiedada!
Thanks, @TisonKun! We might want to change this to a table soon, since the Java 11 PR, #577, appears to be almost ready (waiting for tests to pass).

@rdblue, LGTM. I had only two questions. 

I think we need to update Javadoc in one place and should be good to go.
It is a Javadoc change, I'll merge it.

I also noticed that https://iceberg.apache.org/spark/ only documents metadata tables exposed by catalog like `db.table.files` , `db.table.snapshots`, `db.table.manifests`, etc. and does not cover/mention location based tables e.g. `hdfs://${basePath}#files` ,  `hdfs://${basePath}#snapshots` ,  `hdfs://${basePath}#manifests` etc. For those that don't have Catalog based table access these are useful to know about, One currently needs to go through code to find these. Would be good to document these in the public docs as well.
Thanks, @aokolnychyi, @chenjunjiedada, and @openinx for reviewing!
Thanks for doing this, @rdblue! Shall we take a look at #936 next?
Yes, please do! That one should be easier since it is just updating a few tests to be parameterized.
@rdblue, what about updating `TestSparkReadProjection` as described [here](https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/pull/937#issuecomment-615540803)?

> what about updating TestSparkReadProjection

I think it's reasonable to update the test, but not required. It's always good to reduce duplicated code, but we don't actually need that to support date and timestamp because those aren't tested.
I ran `./gradlew check` locally and everything looks good so I merged this.

@stevenzwu Thanks for the comments and sorry for my late response~~

Regarding:
> We probably need some generic serializer interface.

Yes, I rename "AvroSerializer" into "RecordSerializer" as the generic serializer interface to transform from any input format to Iceberg **Record**

Regarding: 
> We use Avro quite extensively in the streaming pipeline. It would be nice if we can avoid the format conversion and write Avro directly

Got your idea. Opened a new issue as https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/issues/943
